details.title: An inspection-maintenance model for systems with multiple competing processes
details.standardTitle: An inspection-maintenance model for systems with multiple competing processes

p: Wenjian Li received the B.S degree in Mechanical Design, and M.S. degree in Manufacturing Automation from Huazhong University of Science and Technology, China; and the M.S. degree in Statistics, and M.S. degree in Industrial Engineering both from Rutgers University. He recently received the Ph.D in the Department of Industrial and Systems Engineering, Rutgers University, Piscataway, N.J. His dissertation research focuses on reliability and maintenance modeling for degraded systems subject to multiple competing failure processes.

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Ind. & Syst. Eng., Rutgers Univ., Piscataway, NJ, USA
authors.name: Wenjian Li

p: Hoang Pham is Professor and Director of the Undergraduate Program in the Department of Industrial and Systems Engineering at Rutgers University, Piscataway, NJ. Before joining Rutgers, he was a senior engineering specialist at the Boeing Company, Seattle, and the Idaho National Engineering Laboratory, Idaho Falls. His research interests include software reliability, warranty modeling and optimization, reliability modeling, maintenance, and environmental risk assessment.

He is the author of two books: Software Reliability (Springer-Verlag, 2000), and System Software Reliability (Springer, forthcoming 2005); and is the editor of the Handbook of Reliability Engineering (Springer-Verlag, 2003), and Springer Handbook of Engineering Statistics (Springer, 2005). He is the editor of Springer Series in Reliability. He has published more than 75 journal articles, 20 book chapters, and the editor of ten volumes.

He is editor-in-chief of the International Journal of Reliability, Quality and Safety Engineering, associate editor of the IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man and Cybernetics, and guest editor of IIE Transactions on Quality and Reliability and International Journal of Systems Science. He was Guest Editor of the IEEE Transactions on Reliability, Journal of Systems and Software, the International Journal of Modeling and Simulation, and IEEE Communications. He is on the editorial board of the International Journal of Systems Science, Journal of Computer and Software Engineering, IIE Transactions on Quality and Reliability, and International Journal of Plant Engineering and Management. He has been conference chair and program chair of over 20 international conferences and workshops and is the Conference Chair of the Eleventh International Conference on Reliability and Quality in Design (2005). He is a fellow of the IEEE.

He received the B.S. degree in mathematics, and B.S. degree in computer science, both with high honors, from Northeastern Illinois University, Chicago, the M.S. degree in statistics from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, and the M.S. and Ph.D. degrees in industrial engineering from the State University of New York at Buffalo.

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Ind. & Syst. Eng., Rutgers Univ., Piscataway, NJ, USA
authors.name: Hoang Pham

details.abstract: In some applications, the failure rate of the system depends not only on the time, but also upon the status of the system, such as vibration level, efficiency, number of random shocks on the system, etc., which causes degradation. In this paper, we develop a generalized condition-based maintenance model subject to multiple competing failure processes including two degradation processes, and random shocks. An average long-run maintenance cost rate function is derived based on the expressions for the degradation paths & cumulative shock damage, which are measurable. A geometric sequence is employed to develop the inter-inspection sequence. Upon inspection, one needs to decide whether to perform a maintenance, such as preventive or corrective, or to do nothing. The preventive maintenance thresholds for degradation processes & inspection sequences are the decision variables of the proposed model. We also present an algorithm based on the Nelder-Mead downhill simplex method to calculate the optimum policy that minimizes the average long-run maintenance cost rate. Numerical examples are given to illustrate the results using the optimization algorithm.

kwd: average long-run maintenance cost rate function

citations.title: An inspection-maintenance model for systems with multiple competing processes

context.text: In some cases, if the degradation level exceeds a specified threshold limit, the system may not operate successfully [1].

[1] presented a model based on a Markov approach for predicting the reliability of \$k\$-out-of-\$n\$: \$G\$ systems in which components are subject to multi-stage degradation as well as catastrophic failures.

references.text: R. Bris, E. Chatelet, F. Yalaoui, "New method to minimize the preventive maintenance cost of series-parallel systems", Reliab. Eng. Syst. Saf., vol. 82, pp. 247-255, 2003.

context.text:
Several authors [4]–
[8] have proposed various inspection policies & models for systems with a degradation process.
Grall, Berenguer, and Dieulle [4] studied a system subject to a random deterioration process.
Our research differs from recent studies [3]–[4][9] in several aspects as follows.
Third, the methods, other than Markov, semi-Markov, and the stationary processes, studies in our paper differ from those in [4], [5], [9], [10], [12]–[15].

Consequently, the degradation processes, methods, and the criteria studied in our paper differ from those of [4], [5], [7], [8], [11] [12]–
[14].

references.title: A condition-based maintenance policy for stochastically deteriorating systems
references.text: A. Grall, C. Berenguer, L. Dieulle, "A condition-based maintenance policy for stochastically deteriorating systems", Reliab. Eng. Syst. Saf., vol. 76, pp. 167-180, 2002.

links.abstract: A predictive-maintenance structure for a gradually deteriorating single-unit system (continuous time/continuous state) is presented in this paper. The proposed decision model enables optimal inspection and replacement decision in order to balance the cost engaged by failure and unavailability on an infinite horizon. Two maintenance decision variables are considered: the preventive replacement threshold and the inspection schedule based on the system state. In order to assess the performance of t...

context.text:
Several authors [4]–[5]
[8] have proposed various inspection policies & models for systems with a degradation process.
[5] recently studied the inspection-maintenance strategy for a single unit deteriorating system based on a Gamma process in which it has the stationary & independent increment property.
Our research differs from recent studies [3]–[5][9] in several aspects as follows.

The maintenance decision is made based upon the threshold levels of the degradations, and cumulative shock damage, not on something abstract such as the distribution parameters, or transition probability as other studies [5], [6].
Third, the methods, other than Markov, semi-Markov, and the stationary processes, studies in our paper differ from those in [4], [5], [9], [10], [12]–[15].

Consequently, the degradation processes, methods, and the criteria studied in our paper differ from those of [4], [5], [7], [8], [11] [12]–
[14].

references.title: Continuous-time predictive-maintenance scheduling for a deteriorating system
references.text: A. Grall, L. Dieulle, C. Berenguer, M. Roussignol, "Continuous-time predictive-maintenance scheduling for a deteriorating system", IEEE Trans. Reliab., vol. 51, no. 2, pp. 141-150, 2002.

context.text:
Several authors [4]–[6]
[8] have proposed various inspection policies & models for systems with a degradation process.
Chelbi & Ait-Kadi [6] addressed the optimal inspection strategies for deteriorating equipment subject to preventive & corrective maintenance.
Our research differs from recent studies [3]–[6][9] in several aspects as follows.

The maintenance decision is made based upon the threshold levels of the degradations, and cumulative shock damage, not on something abstract such as the distribution parameters, or transition probability as other studies [5], [6].

references.title: An optimal inspection strategy for randomly failing equipment
references.text: A. Chelbi, D. Ait-Kadi, "An optimal inspection strategy for randomly failing equipment", Reliab. Eng. Syst. Saf., vol. 63, pp. 127-131, 1999.

links.abstract: This paper studies maintained systems with nonself-announcing ("hidden") failures that deteriorate due to both shocks and graceful degradation. Shocks occur according to a Poisson process, shock magnitudes are i.d.d. random variables, and between shocks, deterioration occurs at a constant rate. Inspections are performed periodically. Using regenerative arguments, an expression is derived for limiting average availability. This expression provides insight into the effect of system life distributi...

context.text:
Several authors [4]–[7]
[8] have proposed various inspection policies & models for systems with a degradation process.
Klutke & Yang [7] studied the availability of maintained systems subject to both the effects of the degradation, and random shocks.
Our research differs from recent studies [3]–[7][9] in several aspects as follows.

Consequently, the degradation processes, methods, and the criteria studied in our paper differ from those of [4], [5], [7], [8], [11] [12]–
[14].

references.title: Replacement-repair policy for multi-state deteriorating products under warranty
references.text: M. J. Zuo, B. Liu, D. N. P. Murthy, "Replacement-repair policy for multi-state deteriorating products under warranty", Eur. J. Oper. Res., vol. 123, pp. 519-530, 2000.

links.abstract: In this paper, we develop a generalized multi-state degraded system reliability model subject to multiple competing failure processes, including two degradation processes, and random shocks. The operating condition of the multi-state systems is characterized by a finite number of states. We also present a methodology to generate the system states when there are multi-failure processes. The model can be used not only to determine the reliability of the degraded systems in the context of multi-sta...

context.text: Li & Pham [9] recently developed a generalized multi-state degraded system reliability model with multiple competing failure processes, however, without considering the inspection-maintenance aspects.
Our research differs from recent studies [3]–[9] in several aspects as follows.

references.title: An optimal inspection and replacement policy for a deteriorating system
references.text: M. Ohnishi, H. Kawai, H. Mine, "An optimal inspection and replacement policy for a deteriorating system", J. Appl. Prob., vol. 23, pp. 973-988, 1986.

links.abstract: This paper presents algorithms for deriving optimal maintenance policies to minimize the mean long-run cost-rate for continuous-time Markov deteriorating systems. The degree of deterioration (except failure) of the system is known only through inspection. The time durations of inspection and replacement are nonnegligible. The costs are for inspection, replacement, operation, and downtime (idle). In particular, the replacement time, replacement cost, and operating cost-rate increase as the system...
